coredata.dc:title: Influence of rare-earth elements doping on thermoelectric properties of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 at high temperature
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2014 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Zhu, Yuanhu
Wang, Chunlei
Su, Wenbin
Liu, Jian
Li, Jichao
Zhang, Xinhua
Mei, Liangmo
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 (Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, and Yb) have been synthesized by the solid state reaction method. Samples with relative densities all over 96% have been obtained. Thermoelectric properties are evaluated between 300 and 1000K. The electrical resistivity shows a typical metal-like conductivity behavior, and at high temperature, 973K, decreases from 36.1mΩcm for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 to 8.6mΩcm for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3. Both the absolute values of Seebeck coefficient and thermal conductivity are reduced by the introduction of second rare-earth element. The highest power factor of 415μW/(K2m) is obtained for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 sample, resulting in the highest dimensionless figure of merit (ZT) 0.25 at 973K. This value shows an improvement of 144% compared with that of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 ceramics at the same temperature.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Ceramics
Sintering
Electrical characterization
Thermoelectric effects

head.ce:title: Influence of rare-earth elements doping on thermoelectric properties of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 at high temperature

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Physics, State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Physics, State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 (Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, and Yb) have been synthesized by the solid state reaction method. Samples with relative densities all over 96% have been obtained. Thermoelectric properties are evaluated between 300 and 1000K. The electrical resistivity shows a typical metal-like conductivity behavior, and at high temperature, 973K, decreases from 36.1mΩcm for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 to 8.6mΩcm for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3. Both the absolute values of Seebeck coefficient and thermal conductivity are reduced by the introduction of second rare-earth element. The highest power factor of 415μW/(K2m) is obtained for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 sample, resulting in the highest dimensionless figure of merit (ZT) 0.25 at 973K. This value shows an improvement of 144% compared with that of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 ceramics at the same temperature.

The Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 (Re=La, Pr, …, Yb) were prepared by solid state reaction. Highest ZT value obtained is 0.25 at 973K for Re=Yb, which shows 144% improvement compared with Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 (Re=La, Pr, …, Yb) are produced by solid state reaction.
Lowest resistivity is obtained due to the highest carrier mobility for Re=Yb.
Highest power factor obtained is 415μW/(K2m) at 973K for Re=Yb.
Highest ZT value obtained is 0.25 at 973K for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 sample.

ce:section.ce:para: Thermoelectric (TE) materials have drawn renewed interest, because of their property in converting heat into electricity directly. The thermoelectric performance of TE materials is evaluated by the dimensionless figure of merit ZT=S 2 T/(ρκ), where S, T, ρ and κ are the Seebeck coefficient, absolute temperature, electrical resistivity and thermal conductivity, respectively. Conventional TE materials already in practical applications are always based on alloy materials, such as SiGe [1], Bi2Te3 [2], PbTe [3], and more recently skutterudites [4], etc. Compared with TE alloys, metal oxides have their advantages in better chemical stability, better oxidation resistance, less toxic and lower cost. Oxides had not been considered to be candidates as TE materials due to their low carrier mobility, until the discovery of high-performance TE oxide Na x CoO2 by Terasaki [5]. Thereafter, cobalt-based oxides, such as Ca–Co–O [6–8], Bi–Sr–Co–O [9–11], have been fabricated as p-type legs in TE oxide modulus [12–14]. However, as a counterpart, there are relatively few n-type oxide materials to be studied. Among the n-type TE oxides, CaMnO3 can be synthesized in ambient atmospheric condition and shows excellent TE properties [15], which make it a prospective candidate as n-type oxide TE material. Thermoelectric performance of CaMnO3 substituted with rare-earth metals was first reported by Shimada et al. [16] and Ohtaki et al. [17]. And following doping experiments were carried out with some other trivalent elements by Koumoto et al. [18] and Funahashi et al. [19]. They found that lanthanide elements doping at Ca site is an effective way to increase electrical conductivity while retaining a moderate absolute Seebeck coefficient. Wang et al. [20–22] studied all lanthanide elements substitution with a higher concentration of 10% and reported a large thermoelectric response of CaMnO3 by substituting Dy at Ca site. It indicated that Dy was an optimized dopant in CaMnO3 system. Shortly thereafter, Liu et al. [23,24] found that a lower Dy doping level of 2% would lead to a significant modification in CaMnO3. It showed a lower doping level that would work, which gave us a chance to introduce a second element into CaMnO3 without any second phase. Also there are some studies showing that dual doping is more effective to improve transport properties of CaMnO3 ceramics [25,26]. On basis of this, we reported the thermoelectric performance of dual doped CaMnO3 and obtained a remarkable ZT=0.21 in Ca0.96Dy0.02Bi0.02MnO3 [27]. This result indicates that 2% dual doping is effective in improving thermoelectric performance of CaMnO3.

In order to further study the influence of dual doping on TE performance of CaMnO3 ceramics, it is a good choice to carry out the second element doping on Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 ceramics. Herein, in this paper we prepared Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, Yb, and also Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 (marked as CDM in tables and figures) as a comparison. The influence of the second rare-earth element doping on electrical conductivity, Seebeck coefficient and thermal conductivity was investigated.

Solid state reaction method was used to synthesize samples of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 ceramics, with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, and Yb, respectively. The starting materials were CaCO3 (99.8%), MnO2 (99.9%), Dy2O3 (4N), La2O3 (4N), Pr2O3 (4N), Sm2O3 (4N), Eu2O3 (4N), Ho2O3 (4N), and Yb2O3 (4N). All of the starting materials come from the same supplier of Sinopharm Group Co., Ltd. These raw materials were weighed in stoichiometric proportions and mixed by ball-milling in ethanol with zirconia balls for 12h. After the wet mixtures dried, the powder was calcinated for 12h at 1423K and 12h at 1523K in ambient atmospheric condition with an intermediate grinding. The calcined powder was ball-milled for 12h to obtain a fine powder, which were parched in an oven. The products were pressed into pellets at 350MPa with a tubular forming mold, and sintered in air at 1573K for 12h.

X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using a Bruker AXS D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and scanning (a step width of 0.020°) over the angular range 20–80°. The experimental density of the samples was measured by the Archimedes method. The electrical resistivity measurements were carried out with a standard four-probe in a helium atmosphere, and the Seebeck coefficient was measured simultaneously in the temperature range between 300 and 1000K using LINSEIS LSR-3 equipment. Thermal conductivity values (κ) were calculated from the thermal diffusivity (λ), the specific heat capacity (C
p ), and the density (d) by applying the following relationship:
(1)
κ = λ
C
p
d .

The thermal diffusivity and specific heat capacity were measured with a laser flash apparatus (Netzsch LFA 457) and different thermal analyzer (Netzsch STA 449C), respectively. The electronic carrier concentration n and the mobility μ were measured on an ACCENT HL5500 Hall System.

The XRD patterns for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 are shown in Fig. 1. All the samples are observed to be composed of a single-phase with orthorhombic perovskite structure described by Pnma space group [23–27]. No peak of secondary phase was observed, which suggests that the Dy3+ and Re3+ ions have entered into the CaMnO3 lattice. Lattice parameters are obtained from the X-ray data, meanwhile lattice volume and theoretical density are calculated and are listed in Table 1. Compared with Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, all dual-doped samples show increased parameters. However, except that the ionic radii of La3+ (1.16Å) and Pr3+ (1.126Å) are a bit larger than that of Ca2+ (1.12Å), all the radii of Sm3+ (1.079Å), Eu3+ (1.066Å), Ho3+ (1.015Å),and Yb3+ (0.985Å) are smaller compared to that of Ca2+ (1.12Å) [28]. So the plausible explaination of the increasing lattice is the increasing value of Mn3+/Mn4+, due to the different sizes in the ionic radii between Mn3+ (0.645Å) and Mn4+ (0.530Å) [28]. This phenomenon has also been reported by us in Dy/Bi dual-doping CaMnO3 [27]. Experimental densities are 4.561g/cm3, 4.586g/cm3, 4.534g/cm3, 4.597g/cm3, 4.556g/cm3, 4.590g/cm3, 4.575g/cm3, for samples Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and dual doped samples with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, Yb, respectively. The experimental density increases with second element introduced into CDM, mainly due to the contribution from the heavier mass of Re elements compared with Ca. The relative densities, defined as the experimental density over the theoretical density, are all over 96%, which means the samples are of good compactness.

Fig. 2 shows the temperature dependence of electrical resistivity Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 ceramics. The electrical resistivity increases with increasing temperature, which is indicative of their metallic-like conductivity behavior. This behavior has been also observed in other doped CaMnO3 samples [21–27]. At high temperature, 973K, the values of resistivity are obtained 36.1mΩcm, 11.6mΩcm, 12.4mΩcm, 11.5mΩcm, 13.7mΩcm, 13.2mΩcm, 8.6mΩcm for samples of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3, with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, Yb, respectively. It is obvious that the resistivity decreases remarkably as the second element introduced into Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3. Usually, the electrical resistivity ρ could be approximately expressed as a function of carrier density n and mobility μ:ρ=1/neμ, where e is the elementary charge of a carrier. The measured carrier concentration n and mobility μ at temperature are listed in Table 2. It can be seen that both the n and μ are increased with the second element introduced into Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3. For Re=Yb, the n is increased from 1.05×1019 cm−1 of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 sample to 1.61×1019 cm−1, and the μ is increased from 3.3cm2/Vs of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 sample to 11.2cm2/Vs. These two values are both the highest for all samples. In Table 2, Re=Yb sample shows a remarkable value of mobility (μ), which is the main reason of its lowest resistivity among all samples. As is known, mobility is determined by effective mass, which is determined by the slope of bands. So, lower mobility should be dominated by higher values of slope of bands, which indicates that Yb doping introduces some more bending energy bands, or bends some bands in conductive band. Yet, the origin of the behavior for Yb doping is still unclear, and more work is needed to resolve it.

Assuming the thermal activated carrier density, the electrical conductivity of perovskite-type manganite can be expressed as presented in Eq. (2)
(2)
σ = C / T
exp ( −

κ
B
T )
where C, T, E
α , and κ
B are the constant, the absolute temperature, the activation energy and the Boltzmann constant, respectively. Therefore, we can estimate the activation energy E
α from the Arrhenius plots of ln(σT) versus 1000/T as shown in Fig. 3. A good linear relationship could be found in Fig. 3 for all samples, which is in accord with previous reports [17,25–27], indicating a typical small polaron hopping conduction [17]. The activation energy E
α is 24meV for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, and for Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3, with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, and Yb, the values are 18meV, 21meV, 17meV, 17meV, 19meV, and 20meV, respectively. Compared with the activation energy of CaMnO3 [17], these values are rather lower. This result shows that a considerable decrease of activation energy due to the addition of dual doping induces an increase in electrical conductivity over that of CaMnO3. It is also noticed that the deviations from linearity appear in Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, at high temperature, as circled in Fig. 3. We contribute the deviations to intrinsic activation, which would certainly occur at high temperature for semiconductor. And we believe that this kind of deviation from linearity for Re=Yb sample would occur at higher temperature beyond which we measured. This deserves further investigation.

Temperature dependence of Seebeck coefficients for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 and Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 ceramics is shown in Fig. 4. In the temperature range between 300K and 1000K, the Seebeck coefficients of all samples are negative, which is indicative of an n-type electrical conduction behavior. The sample of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 has a relatively large Seebeck coefficient, being about −300μV/K at 973K. As the second additional element is introduced into Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, the dual doping samples show relatively smaller Seebeck coefficients. This phenomenon can also be found in previous reports by Koumoto et al. [18] and Park et al. [25], they attributed the decrease of Seebeck coefficients to the increasing carrier concentration. Generally, in perovskite CaMnO3 system, the tendencies of the temperature dependences of Seebeck coefficient and electrical conductivity are opposite to each other. As is known, the values of Seebeck coefficient decrease with the increase of temperature, while the electrical conductivity increases with the increase of temperature for CaMnO3 system [16,17]. However, as one can see, the values of Seebeck coefficients of all samples become saturated at high temperature. This phenomenon is a puzzle, and also found in some other doped CaMnO3 system [21–27]. Liu et al. [23,24] found the same phenomenon in system of Ca0.98Re0.02MnO3−δ and suggested that the mixed valence of Mn4+ and Mn3+ mainly arose from oxygen deficiency δ and the diffusion Seebeck coefficient of CaMnO3−δ can be expressed as

ex is positive. Due to the different E
α for intrinsic carriers or extrinsic carriers, the two terms would certainly result in a rapid change in value for different temperature range. As a result, the first term dominates the Seebeck coefficient in low temperature and leads to a larger absolute value, and the second dominates it in high temperature and saturates the absolute value. Therefore, the absolute value of Seebeck coefficient would be saturated and even decreased for high temperature. From Eq. (3) we can also expect the absolute value of Seebeck coefficient decrease in higher temperature range. This phenomenon has already been found in Dy/Bi dual doped samples [27], which could also confirm the validity of Eq. (3) in turn.

Power factor is calculated from Seebeck coefficient and electrical resistivity as S
2
/ρ. The temperature dependence of power factor is shown in Fig. 5. In the temperature range between 300K and 1000K, power factors do not change dramatically with temperature for all samples. The highest values for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, and for Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3, with Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, and Yb, the values are 257μW/(K2m), 350μW/(K2m), 332μW/(K2m), 381μW/(K2m), 332μW/(K2m), 336μW/(K2m), and 415μW/(K2m), respectively. We can see that Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 ceramics sample exhibits the highest value of power factor. This is related with the decreasing of electrical resistivity while maintaining a reasonable value of Seebeck coefficient by dual doping of Dy and Yb. Power factors for dual doped samples are all larger than that of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, which means that introducing second element is an effective way in improving the thermoelectric transport property.

Temperature dependence of thermal conductivity between 300K and 1000K is shown in Fig. 6. Limited to the measurement, the thermal conductivity is only measured for the three samples (Re=La, Sm, Yb) with power factor over 350μW/(K2m), and Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 as a comparison. The total thermal conductivity (κ) is shown in Fig. 6(a). The lowest thermal conductivity is 1.47W/mK at 973K for sample of Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3, which is much lower than 2.20W/mK for Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 at the same temperature. And all three dual doped samples show lower thermal conductivity compared with Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, which indicates that introducing the second element could further reduce the thermal conductivity in CaMnO3 system.Usually, electronic thermal conductivity is determined by Wiedemann–Franz law: κ
e =LTσ, where L=2.45×10−8 WΩK−2 is the Lorenz number, σ is the electrical conductivity, and T is the absolute temperature. However, for most thermoelectric materials, the real Lorenz number is lower than 2.45×10−8 WΩK−2, depending on the reduced Fermi energy ξ=E

In the above equations, k
B is the Boltzmann constant, and e is the electron charge. Meanwhile, acoustic phonon scattering has been assumed as the main carrier scattering mechanism, so, r=−1/2 [30]. The Lorenz number can be obtained by applying the calculated reduced Fermi energy ξ and scattering parameter r into Eq. (4). As shown in Fig. 6(b), all of the Lorenz numbers range from nondegenerate limit (1.5×10−8 WΩK−2) to the degenerate limit (2.45×10−8 WΩK−2) [31]. On the basis of the above calculation for Lorenz number, the lattice thermal conductivity (κ
lat ) can be estimated by subtracting κ
e from κ, shown in Fig. 6(c). Comparing Fig. 6(c) to Fig. 6(a), the value of lattice thermal conductivity is close to that of total thermal conductivity, indicating that the thermal conductivity mainly comes from the lattice thermal conductivity. According to the study of Wang et al. [20], the low lattice thermal conductivity for dual doping samples is mainly due to the variation in lattice vibration of the system strongly caused by Re3+ doping. The effect of Re3+ doping on the lattice vibration arises from two main factors. One is that the weight of Re3+ is much higher than Ca2+. So the Re3+ ions can vibrate independently from the other ions, which would cause large local vibrations [20]. As a result, the mean free path of phonons will be shortened, and thus κ
lat will be markedly suppressed. The other factor is the crystallographic distortion caused by the change in ionic radius, which would cause further reduction in κ
lat
[17]. In general, the second element (Re) lead to stronger resonance and dislocations scattering, which results in reducing the lattice thermal conductivity.

Temperature dependence of dimensionless figure-of-merit ZT is shown in Fig. 7. The ZT values for all the samples increase with increasing temperature over the entire temperature range. The highest ZT value obtained is 0.25 at 973K for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 sample, due to its low values of ρ and κ, and moderate value of S. This value represents an improvement of 144% compared with that of Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 example. Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 exhibited a ZT value that is in agreement with reported by Liu et al. [23,24]. All dual doped samples present a higher value of ZT than Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3, suggesting it to effectively introduce the second element into Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 for a higher thermoelectric performance.

The influence of rare-earth element doping at the Ca site on the thermoelectric properties of Ca0.96Dy0.02 Re 0.02MnO3 (Re=La, Pr, Sm, Eu, Ho, Yb) ceramics have been investigated in temperature range between 300K and 1000K to improve the thermoelectric performance of n-type oxide materials. All samples were single phase with orthorhombic structure. Thermoelectric properties are investigated. The influence of dual doping on the thermoelectric performance is found effective in reducing the electrical resistivity and thermal conductivity, meanwhile retaining a moderate absolute Seebeck coefficient. A suitable dual-doping (Re=Yb) lead to highest mobility, resulting in a remarkable increase of figure of merit. The highest ZT=0.25 at 973K is obtained for Ca0.96Dy0.02Yb0.02MnO3 sample, and it is 144% increased compared with Ca0.98Dy0.02MnO3 ceramics. These results suggest that 2% dual doping of rare-earth element at the Ca site of the CaMnO3 would lead to high thermoelectric performance.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The work is financially supported by the National Basic Research Program of China under Grant no. 2013CB632506, the National Natural Science Foundation of China (11374186, 51231007 and 51202132), and Independent Innovation Foundation of Shandong University, IIFSDU.
